segment.source: Logging Mode
segment.target: Logging Mode

segment.source: Logging Mode
segment.target: Logging Mode

segment.source: Logging Mode
segment.target: Logging Mode

segment.source: When you define a Windows Performance Recorder (WPR) profile, you must select a logging mode from the following options:
segment.target: When you define a Windows Performance Recorder (WPR) profile, you must select a logging mode from the following options:

segment.source: File: records logging data to a sequential file
segment.target: File: records logging data to a sequential file

segment.source: Memory: records logging data to circular buffers in memory
segment.target: Memory: records logging data to circular buffers in memory

segment.source: The logging mode is set to Memory by default.
segment.target: The logging mode is set to Memory by default.

segment.source: However, On/off transitions are always logged to a file.
segment.target: However, On/off transitions are always logged to a file.

segment.source: Logging to file is typically used for short recordings for which you can anticipate the events that will be recorded.
segment.target: Logging to file is typically used for short recordings for which you can anticipate the events that will be recorded.

segment.source: Logging to memory is typically used to log events that can occur at any time.
segment.target: Logging to memory is typically used to log events that can occur at any time.

segment.source: When WPR logs to memory, buffer size and the level of profile detail determine how long WPR can log data before old events are overwritten.
segment.target: When WPR logs to memory, buffer size and the level of profile detail determine how long WPR can log data before old events are overwritten.

segment.source: Caution
segment.target: Caution

segment.source: To limit file size, choose Memory.
segment.target: To limit file size, choose Memory.

segment.source: When logging to file, available disk space is the only limitation to file size.
segment.target: When logging to file, available disk space is the only limitation to file size.

segment.source: If the file is too large, you might not be able to analyze it in Windows Performance Analyzer (WPA).
segment.target: If the file is too large, you might not be able to analyze it in Windows Performance Analyzer (WPA).

segment.source: When you author custom recording profiles, you must define both a file and a memory version in the same recording profile definition (.wprp) file.
segment.target: When you author custom recording profiles, you must define both a file and a memory version in the same recording profile definition (.wprp) file.

segment.source: When you select a profile for a recording, you must select either the file or memory version to use for that recording event.
segment.target: When you select a profile for a recording, you must select either the file or memory version to use for that recording event.

segment.source: For examples of custom profiles, see 3. Profile Definitions.
segment.target: For examples of custom profiles, see 3. Profile Definitions.

segment.source: A .wprp file can have up to four profile definitions: one for each combination of detail level and logging mode.
segment.target: A .wprp file can have up to four profile definitions: one for each combination of detail level and logging mode.

segment.source: The following constraints are enforced:
segment.target: The following constraints are enforced:

segment.source: The profile identifier must be in the following format: ProfileName.DetailLevel.LoggingMode
segment.target: The profile identifier must be in the following format: ProfileName.DetailLevel.LoggingMode

segment.source: All profiles that exist in a single file must have the same name.
segment.target: All profiles that exist in a single file must have the same name.

segment.source: A .wprp file must contain profiles for both memory and file logging modes.
segment.target: A .wprp file must contain profiles for both memory and file logging modes.

segment.source: When you author a custom profile, you must define the BufferSize element and the Buffers element.
segment.target: When you author a custom profile, you must define the BufferSize element and the Buffers element.

segment.source: You can define the total amount of buffer as a fixed number of buffers by using a size that you define in kilobytes (KB), or as a percentage of total memory.
segment.target: You can define the total amount of buffer as a fixed number of buffers by using a size that you define in kilobytes (KB), or as a percentage of total memory.

segment.source: The default buffer count is 64, and the default buffer size is 128 KB.
segment.target: The default buffer count is 64, and the default buffer size is 128 KB.

segment.source: You can use the WPR command-line interface to view the size and number of buffers that each provider uses.
segment.target: You can use the WPR command-line interface to view the size and number of buffers that each provider uses.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: WPR supports only single-value NumberOfBuffers.
segment.target: WPR supports only single-value NumberOfBuffers.

segment.source: It does not support minimum and maximum buffers.
segment.target: It does not support minimum and maximum buffers.

segment.source: General guidelines about how to set buffers are as follows:
segment.target: General guidelines about how to set buffers are as follows:

segment.source: Event stacks require more space compared to events without stacks.
segment.target: Event stacks require more space compared to events without stacks.

segment.source: Therefore, WPR uses more buffers and logs more data for the same amount of time.
segment.target: Therefore, WPR uses more buffers and logs more data for the same amount of time.

segment.source: Make sure that your buffers are properly sized.
segment.target: Make sure that your buffers are properly sized.

segment.source: If buffers are too large, too much memory is consumed and system performance is impacted.
segment.target: If buffers are too large, too much memory is consumed and system performance is impacted.

segment.source: If buffers are too small, events can be lost, and the trace becomes useless.
segment.target: If buffers are too small, events can be lost, and the trace becomes useless.

segment.source: When logging to memory, buffer size determines how long WPR can log data before old events are overwritten.
segment.target: When logging to memory, buffer size determines how long WPR can log data before old events are overwritten.

segment.source: For memory traces, we recommend that you set buffers as a percentage of total memory, such as 1% to 5% of physical memory, depending on the profile.
segment.target: For memory traces, we recommend that you set buffers as a percentage of total memory, such as 1% to 5% of physical memory, depending on the profile.

segment.source: Unless the recording profile is unusually verbose, 10% of physical memory should be sufficient.
segment.target: Unless the recording profile is unusually verbose, 10% of physical memory should be sufficient.

segment.source: Buffers are typically smaller when logging to a file than when logging to memory.
segment.target: Buffers are typically smaller when logging to a file than when logging to memory.

segment.source: However, if the buffers are too small, the buffers will flush to disk too often.
segment.target: However, if the buffers are too small, the buffers will flush to disk too often.

segment.source: Unless the recording profile is unusually verbose, 10-50 MB of physical memory should be sufficient.
segment.target: Unless the recording profile is unusually verbose, 10-50 MB of physical memory should be sufficient.

segment.source: For more guidance about buffers, see Sessions (Windows Drivers).
segment.target: For more guidance about buffers, see Sessions (Windows Drivers).

segment.target: Related topics
